title: Compiler Part 3 - Integration testing
description: In todays blog post we are going to implement assert so we can start writing tests.

children.value: In todays blog post we are going to implement
so we can start writing tests.
And as always you can find the code

Simple, testing, we could test using stdout, but that gets annoying as we need to keep track of expected output somewhere, and an assert statement is just way more convenient. Our assert statement is gonna take the format of
(message will be optional). That means we will add string to our tokenizer today! but we wont implement full on strings until later posts.
We are going to start with just
at the end. This will also give us a look at how
s are structured, as that is really all asserts are!

props.code: assert x == 2, "stuff broke";

children.value: So now that we are writing tests breaking changes are gonna become annoying as we have to update tests. So we are going to avoid them as best we can!
Put that posses a question, we dont have a
function yet, we dont have functions at all. Should we add the very minimal to support
, or just have stuff at the top level? But then in the future should we ever add
and what does that mean? If we dont we have to somehow separate the stuff that should go in
and what is actually top level, and that would only work in the
file! In other words it is a bit of a pain :/
So we need a way to specify a
, but also do we want to have
be some special name like every other lang out there, or should we be a snowflake? Since doing half the work of adding functions is kinda annoying, we could have special syntax for main!
It is a bit unusual to be sure, but I think this might work for us!
So we are gonna now introduce two type of statement, TopLevel and Normal statements, TopLevel is stuff like imports, functions, main, struct. While normal is stuff like assignment, print, if, etc...
We are going to need some new tokens, for

props.code:
// lib.rs
pub enum TokenType {
    Integer(IntType),
    Identifier(String),
    Print,
    SemiColon,
    Dollar,
    CurlyOpen,
    CurlyClose,
    Eof,
}

And now for the fun part, code gen! I mentioned that we could use blocks when doing
s, well asserts are just implicit
s, so we will create 2 blocks for the assert, "Continue" and "Failure". We are also going to need
to make our job easier, then we create a branch. So
If you run this you should see
printed, and if you run with
you might have expected to see the assert code in there... but we dont? why?
Optimizations! if you also run with

you now see the assert logic, but LLVM figured out that it is always True so just removed it! great for speed, but there is one downside, LLVM might remove code that weren't being used by accident. Say we had a bug that somehow caused our
to give out the wrong result, llvm would just optimize away the comparison itself and just leave us with the code that would get run. oh no! that is why the
flag is so important for debugging, if the llvm ir doesn't match what you would expect always try running with that first to see what we actually generated.
Well we got asserts, now lets write some tests! This is gonna be pretty simple, we will loop over all files in
Lets add some tests right now!
Surely this should not fail! But you never known
/// Compile and run all files in integration_tests/
and it should run the test.
so we can actually test stuff! We will implement this for numbers, then in the next blog post we will add other comparisons, logic operators and binary ops.
Now we are going to start doing some TTD, so lets write some tests first!
Now we are getting into double symbols, we could have just a
symbol, but, we will have a
at this time even though we wont use it yet.
We will add a function to help us eat these double symbols
Then we will add comparisons to our AST!
because we cant have recursive types, because it would be infinitely large, but
puts the object on the heap, meaning we it isnt a problem!
Now parsing binary ops is actually a good amount of work, at least when we have multiple. Why you ask? Order of operations! We might parse
if we just go right to left, which is fine, but
, which is not good. So we need to parse them in the correct order, and we need to do it in a way that is easy to add more operators later.

So how are we gonna do that? We aren't! ... what? Well it is a bit of work, and not the focus of this blog post. And we only have one operator so far so it wont be an issue, but we will get back to this in the next post!
Now we add the IR for the binary op
This is a bit more complex than the AST, but again type info! So all these types are needed to make code gen easy
In the next post we will make this proper, but for now it is pretty hardcoded.
And now the fun part begins, code gen!
And now running our test should work!
And congratulations! We now have a working testing framework, this is gonna make our future development much more convenient. in the next post we will add more fun tests like
! But we will go into that in detail in the next post.
